constructs.name: Novelty_Seeking_Trait
constructs.description: Stable personality tendency to seek stimulation, variety, and new experiences

constructs.name: Work_Role_Fragmentation
constructs.description: Degree to which job/role requires attending to multiple distinct responsibilities and domains

constructs.name: Context_Switching_Frequency
constructs.description: How often one makes unplanned switches between tasks, apps, or attentional targets

constructs.name: Sleep_Quality
constructs.description: Restorative quality of sleep the previous night

constructs.name: General_Stress_Level
constructs.description: Overall psychological stress and pressure experienced

constructs.name: Cognitive_Fatigue
constructs.description: Mental tiredness and depleted cognitive resources

constructs.name: Self_Regulation_Capacity
constructs.description: Available capacity to control impulses and regulate behavior

constructs.name: Perceived_Task_Overwhelm
constructs.description: Feeling of having too much to do and being unable to manage it all

constructs.name: Switching_Habit_Strength
constructs.description: Automaticity and strength of habitual context-switching behavior patterns

constructs.name: Task_Engagement_Level
constructs.description: Degree of absorption, focus, and involvement in the current task

constructs.name: Task_Aversiveness
constructs.description: How unpleasant, difficult, or unappealing current tasks feel

constructs.name: Boredom_Understimulation
constructs.description: Feeling understimulated, lacking interest, or insufficiently engaged

constructs.name: Anxious_Restlessness
constructs.description: Jittery anxiety, inability to sit still, urge to do something else

constructs.name: Task_Clarity
constructs.description: Knowing clearly what to do next and how to proceed with work

constructs.name: Notification_Interruption_Load
constructs.description: Amount of external notifications, pings, and interruptions received

constructs.name: Digital_Environment_Friction
constructs.description: Barriers and friction built into digital environment that make switching harder

edges.description: Higher task engagement reduces the pull toward switching contexts
Greater self-regulation allows resisting impulses to switch
Stronger habits make switching more automatic and frequent
Restless anxiety drives seeking relief through switching
Boredom drives seeking novelty through switching
More notifications trigger more context switches
Higher friction makes switching more effortful and less frequent
Higher novelty-seeking increases baseline tendency toward switching
More aversive tasks increase escape-motivated switching
Higher stress impairs sleep quality
Overstimulation from switching disrupts sleep restoration
Poor sleep increases stress reactivity and baseline stress
Feeling overwhelmed directly increases stress
Fragmented roles with multiple demands create ongoing stress
Poor sleep leads to starting the day already fatigued
Chronic stress depletes cognitive resources
Frequent switching is cognitively expensive and depleting
Low physical energy contributes to mental fatigue
Good sleep restores self-regulation resources
Mental fatigue depletes self-regulation capacity
Physical energy supports self-regulation efforts
Stress depletes self-regulation resources
Fragmented roles with many domains create overwhelm
Switching prevents task completion, accumulating unfinished work
Good sleep restores physical energy
Each switching episode reinforces and strengthens the habit
Clear understanding of what to do enables deeper engagement
Aversive tasks reduce willingness to engage
Mental fatigue impairs ability to engage deeply
Physical energy supports sustained engagement
Boredom reflects and causes disengagement from tasks
Restless state interferes with focused engagement
When tired, tasks feel more difficult and aversive
Stress magnifies negative perception of tasks
Overwhelm makes individual tasks feel more daunting
Unclear tasks feel more aversive due to uncertainty
High novelty seekers are more prone to boredom
Clear tasks provide direction that reduces boredom
Tedious aversive tasks create boredom
Stress manifests as anxious, restless state
Overwhelm creates anxiety and restless urge to act
Constant notifications create vigilant, restless state
Poor sleep increases anxiety reactivity
Fatigue reduces emotional regulation, increasing restlessness
Mental fatigue impairs clear thinking about tasks
Overwhelm clouds judgment about what to prioritize
Higher friction environments reduce notification exposure
Self-regulation enables proactive environment design

indicators.name: topic_switch_count
indicators.how_to_measure: Count each time the user moves from one browsing subject to a clearly unrelated subject. Examples: programming to travel, health to music, work to entertainment. Each transition between unrelated topics counts as 1.

indicators.name: single_page_topic_count
indicators.how_to_measure: Count topics where the user visited only 1 page before switching to a different topic. Each topic abandoned after a single page/search counts as 1.

indicators.name: late_night_activity
indicators.how_to_measure: Check if any entry has a timestamp between 11:00 PM and 5:00 AM. Record 1 if any such entries exist, 0 if none.

indicators.name: sleep_related_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches or page titles containing: sleep, insomnia, tired, fatigue, melatonin, nap, rest, 'waking up', 'can't sleep', or sleep tracker products.

indicators.name: stress_anxiety_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches or page titles containing: stress, anxiety, anxious, overwhelm, panic, mental health, calm, relax, meditation, breathing exercises, or therapy.

indicators.name: health_symptom_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches about symptoms, side effects, drug safety, 'is X dangerous', disease names, or medical conditions that suggest health-related worry.

indicators.name: typo_search_count
indicators.how_to_measure: Count search queries with obvious spelling errors, misspellings, jumbled letters, or missing letters that suggest reduced attention.

indicators.name: entertainment_site_visits
indicators.how_to_measure: Count visits to entertainment sites: YouTube non-tutorial videos, Netflix, Spotify, gaming sites, streaming platforms, or leisure subreddits like r/videos or r/funny.

indicators.name: focus_tool_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches containing: focus app, website blocker, pomodoro, productivity tool, 'how to concentrate', distraction blocker, or self-control app.

indicators.name: work_topic_returns
indicators.how_to_measure: Count instances where a work/technical topic appears, then unrelated leisure content appears, then the SAME work topic reappears. Each such return pattern counts as 1.

indicators.name: brief_topic_touches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count distinct topics explored with only 1-2 page visits before switching away. Each topic briefly touched but not explored in depth counts as 1.

indicators.name: organization_tool_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches for: todo list, task manager, Trello, Notion, Asana, 'how to organize', project management, time management, or getting things done.

indicators.name: exercise_fitness_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches or visits about: exercise, workout, gym, running, fitness, sports, health tracker, Oura ring, Fitbit, Whoop, or physical activity.

indicators.name: first_activity_hour
indicators.how_to_measure: Find the first browsing entry of the day and record its hour as a number 0-23. Example: 7:45 AM = 7, 2:15 PM = 14.

indicators.name: habitual_site_visits
indicators.how_to_measure: Count total visits to common habit-forming sites: Reddit.com, news.ycombinator.com, Twitter/X, YouTube homepage, Facebook, or Instagram. Each page visit counts as 1.

indicators.name: adjacent_topic_switches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count pairs of consecutive entries that are on completely unrelated topics. For each pair of adjacent entries (row N and row N+1) about different subjects, count 1.

indicators.name: deep_topic_sessions
indicators.how_to_measure: Count topic sessions with 5 or more consecutive related pages/searches on the same subject. Each extended focused session counts as 1.

indicators.name: progressive_search_chains
indicators.how_to_measure: Count research chains that build progressively deeper: searches that refine or extend prior searches on the same topic. Example: 'Haskell' then 'Haskell monads' then 'Haskell monad tutorial'. Each such chain counts as 1.

indicators.name: workday_leisure_visits
indicators.how_to_measure: For entries timestamped Monday-Friday 9AM-5PM: count visits to entertainment, social media, travel planning, shopping, or non-work leisure content.

indicators.name: procrastination_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches containing: procrastination, motivation, 'how to start', 'can't focus', productivity tips, or explicit references to avoiding or delaying work.

indicators.name: curiosity_exploration_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches driven by idle curiosity with no practical purpose: random Wikipedia browsing, 'what is X' questions, trivia, definitions, or exploring random interesting topics.

indicators.name: distinct_category_count
indicators.how_to_measure: Count how many distinct topic categories appear. Categories include: programming, health, travel, food, music, news, shopping, entertainment, finance, sports. Each unique category present counts as 1.

indicators.name: rapid_search_clusters
indicators.how_to_measure: Count clusters of 3 or more searches with timestamps in rapid succession (within a few minutes of each other). Each such burst cluster counts as 1.

indicators.name: news_current_event_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches or visits about current events, breaking news, recent incidents, news sites, or trending topics. Examples: 'nepal plane crash', 'latest news', news.google.com.

indicators.name: repeated_query_count
indicators.how_to_measure: Count search queries that repeat or closely resemble earlier searches from the same day. Same keywords or rephrased versions of same question each count as 1.

indicators.name: tutorial_how_to_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches containing: 'how to', tutorial, guide, 'step by step', 'getting started', 'for beginners', or learn followed by a topic.

indicators.name: social_media_visits
indicators.how_to_measure: Count visits to social media platforms: Reddit, Twitter/X, Facebook, Instagram, LinkedIn, TikTok, or Mastodon. Each page visit to these domains counts as 1.

indicators.name: email_messaging_visits
indicators.how_to_measure: Count visits to email or messaging services: Gmail, Outlook, Yahoo Mail, Slack, Discord, Microsoft Teams, or URLs containing 'mail'. Each visit counts as 1.

indicators.name: blocker_app_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches for: website blocker, Cold Turkey, Freedom app, StayFocusd, LeechBlock, app blocker, site blocker, or blocking specific distracting sites.

indicators.name: digital_minimalism_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches about: digital minimalism, dopamine detox, attention management, reducing screen time, digital wellbeing, or decluttering digital environment.

indicators.name: sensation_seeking_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Proxy for Novelty_Seeking_Trait: Count searches or visits related to novel sensory experiences: psychedelics, ketamine, microdosing, LSD, psilocybin, 'what does X feel like', extreme sports, skydiving, bungee, or experimental substances. Each search/visit counts as 1.

indicators.name: travel_destination_variety
indicators.how_to_measure: Proxy for Novelty_Seeking_Trait: Count distinct geographic destinations researched: cities, countries, islands, beaches, or regions being explored for travel. Examples from data: Sicily, Crete, Peru, Villach. Each unique destination counts as 1.

indicators.name: distinct_technical_stack_count
indicators.how_to_measure: Proxy for Work_Role_Fragmentation: Count distinct programming languages, frameworks, or technical platforms appearing in searches/visits that suggest active work: Ruby, Haskell, Python, Scala, authentication systems (auth0, okta), cryptography (TLS, AES), infrastructure (Linux, Docker). Each distinct technology stack counts as 1.

indicators.name: professional_domain_categories
indicators.how_to_measure: Proxy for Work_Role_Fragmentation: Count distinct professional/work domain categories appearing: software development, security/cryptography, system administration, academic research, product/business. Categorize work-related searches and count unique categories present. Example: Ruby debugging (dev) + TLS research (security) + auth0 comparison (product) = 3.
